Hatching an Egg

Blade could hardly wait for Vespera to lay her egg. And then after that, he would have to wait for it to hatch! He felt all too excited and he didn't want to wait however many months it would take. Akir was really excited too, but he tried not to act like it. Blade could easily tell, since Akir would check on Vespera almost every day to see if she laid the egg.

It wasn't until three weeks later that Akir came bursting through their door, startling Talia who had been resting in her wooden chair, and Blade who was lying next to her.

He hardly gave them a chance to ask what was happening before he said, "She laid the egg!”

Blade hopped up onto his paws, his tail swishing excitedly behind him. "R-really?”

Akir nodded and beckoned with his wings for Blade to come. Blade glanced at Talia with a big, toothy smile. She returned the smile and urged him to go with the wave of her hands. Blade nodded and quickly padded out the door. He and Akir took off to the skies, flapping their wings as they angled towards Vespera's home.

They arrived in no time, and Vespera invited them in moments later. Blade dipped his head in greeting and she did the same with a grin.

"Wow, that was fast,” she remarked and giggled. "I guess you two are pretty excited, huh?”

The egg was nestled in a few rolls of furs, gently placed in the middle of the soft protection. Akir and Blade stepped over to it with big smiles on their muzzles. Akir sniffed the egg curiously and looked at Vespera.

"Can I hold it?” he asked.

She nodded and chuckled. "It is your egg after all. As much as I wish I could keep it, I made sure I wouldn't get attached to it. You can take it home with you whenever you want.”

Blade sat next to Akir and watched him hold the egg. He saw a glint of something in his sapphire eyes. He couldn't tell exactly if it was pride or happiness, but it was probably a mixture of both.

"Thank you, Vespera. We'll gladly take it with us.” Akir smiled softly at Blade and handed him the egg. "Careful!”

Blade reached out and grabbed it, pulling it close to his fluffy chest. It was very smooth and as white as his claws. It was heavy, too, about as big as his head. He gently caressed it and felt it teeming with warmth. Blade couldn't shake the smile from his lips. This was his egg that he created. He was going to be a father, and Akir was too! Whatever little hatchling inside would be theirs.

He gave the egg back to Akir who took it and placed it back in the furs. "I can't thank you enough, Vespera... You've made us both very happy.” Blade gave her a kind nuzzle.

"It was my pleasure,” she said. "I think you two will be awesome parents—better than me, anyway!”

Akir chuckled and gave her an affectionate nuzzle. "We'll bring our hatchling around so you can see him or her. It's the least we can do.”

Vespera nodded. "What will you name it? Oh, I hope it's female! Females can have such pretty names.”

Akir glanced back at Blade and shrugged his wings. "We haven't really talked about it.”

"Well, if you need any help, I'd be more than willing! I know a lot of pretty names, and handsome names too.”

"We'll let you know.” Akir grinned and chuckled. "Shall we show Talia our egg?” he asked Blade.

Blade smiled and nodded eagerly. Akir picked the egg up and tucked it carefully against his body. "We'll be around, Vespera,” he said.

She smiled softly and nodded as she stared at the egg. "I'll be here.”

Blade could tell that she was a little sad to see them go. He felt sorry for her, seeing how they were taking the egg that she laid. Even though they had agreed that Blade and Akir were the parents, she was still biologically the mother of their hatchling. Motherly instincts told her to care for her egg, so it must have been hard for her to let it go.

Akir and Blade waved at her with a wing as they stepped out into the bright, sunny day. The door shut behind them, and they took off into the cloudy sky. Akir held the egg firmly against his chest as they flew. A look of determination furrowed his brow, seeming to be putting all of his effort into making sure there was no chance to drop the egg. Blade grinned and flew below him... just in case!

When they returned home, they brought the egg to Talia with big smiles on their faces. She chuckled and took the egg and sat it in her lap, admiring it with a kind expression.

"So, you two are going to be parents now?”

Blade nodded excitedly and gave Akir a small kiss. Normally, Akir wasn't very affectionate when Talia was around, but this time he kissed Blade right back without hesitation.

"How long will it take for the egg to hatch?” Blade asked her. He sat on his haunches next to her chair, peering at his egg.

"Oh, I don't know, Blade... Our eggs usually take about a month to hatch. I'm not sure if ferals are the same way or not.”

Blade nodded and hoped that the egg would hatch soon. Blade took it back from Talia and cradled it in his arms with a big, toothy grin spreading his lips. He glanced up at Akir and looked adoringly into his blue eyes.

Akir stepped around behind Blade and embraced him from behind, nuzzling at his neck while he held him against his blue and purple underside. Blade purred affectionately, fluffing up his black and gold feathers. He and Akir both held the egg and watched it together—completely oblivious to Talia, who was smiling softly at them.

"You two remind me a lot of my children,” she said quietly.

Both Blade and Akir looked up at her as she leaned back in her chair, and Blade asked with surprise, "You had children?” Talia had never talked much about her past before. It was never really brought up, but the few times Blade had asked any personal questions she dismissed them.

"I do. Two handsome sons that have moved on from this city—a much better choice than what I made.”

Blade sensed a bit of longing in her voice. "When was the last time you saw them?”

Talia sighed and picked at the armrests to her chair. "Many decades ago,” she answered, "back when my first grandchild was born to my oldest. He and his wife decided that this city wasn't safe to raise their hatchling in, and I couldn't have agreed more. So they took a ship to one of the continents—I'm not sure really where. My youngest stayed with me for several years after until he decided the same, though he did try to get me to come with him.”

Talia stared ahead, her pale-yellow eyes filled with thought. The light from the window caught her face, showing the age in her scales and how dull her green scales really were. Blade wondered how old she actually was, knowing that most two-legs lived half as long as ferals.

"Why did you stay?” Akir asked curiously.

"I was born and raised here... It is my home. People needed me here to tend to them. But as time continued, I was needed less and less. You and Blade have been my only patients in the last two years,” she said glumly. "The city doesn't need me anymore, but I'm too old now to leave.”

"How old are you, Talia?” Blade asked.

She chuckled and shrugged her shoulders. "Too old,” she answered. She pursed her lips and narrowed her eyes at them. "You two should move on too... Find someplace else away from this godforsaken land.”

Akir's embrace tightened around Blade, but he remained silent.

"I've thought about it,” Blade said and nuzzled his mate. "But I haven't talked to Akir about it yet.”

Akir looked away and made a grunt. He seemed to be thinking deeply about something that Blade couldn't place, which brought a little worry to his mind.

"If you can find a ship willing to carry ferals, do it,” Talia stated firmly. "It may just be my bones getting old and jittery, but I feel like there is a storm coming. A big one. Something that will cause a lot of chaos, and I'd hate to see you two get caught in the middle of it.”

"But what about you, Talia?” Blade asked worriedly. "I don't want to leave you behind.”

She smiled and shook her head. "I'll be fine. If I die, then I die. No one will miss me, and I've nothing left on this world.”

Blade thought over her words and curled his tail with hers as he looked into her eyes. "I would miss you...”

"I would too,” Akir said kindly.

Talia's face softened and she turned her head away. "You two...”

Blade placed a paw on her hand resting on the wooden arm of her chair. "If we leave, you should come with us.” Blade had never seen Talia so close to crying before. He squeezed her hand and smiled widely at her.

"I'll think about it,” she said and chuckled.

Akir seemed to mostly be in his own world, not saying much. Every time Blade looked at him, he could see that he was still thinking about something. It made him worry.
